newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH PM HOPEFUL FOR JUNE EU TREATY DEAL.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH PM HOPEFUL FOR JUNE EU TREATY DEAL.

text.p: Finnish Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen said on Friday the European Union stood a good chance of agreeing a new basic treaty at an Amsterdam summit next month.

"The chances of achieving an agreement look relatively good," Lipponen told a news conference ahead of an extraordinary EU summit to be held at Noordwijk in the Netherlands on May 23, where European leaders are expected to discuss the June 16-17 Amsterdam summit.

Lipponen said the Netherlands, currently holding the rotating presidency of the EU, had on Friday circulated a paper containing "95 percent and maybe more" of what is likely to be the content of a treaty to be signed at the meeting.
He said there were still some tough unresolved issues, including institutional matters and voting procedures, and the question of the future size of the European Commission.
"The big countries, which have wanted a big overhaul, will have to face the fact that that would be impossible," he said.
For Finland, a key issue has been repeated assertions that it will not give up its "own" commissioner in any overhaul of EU organisations: "Finland's position remains the same," he said.

Lipponen warned against raising any last-minute issues which may derail the tough process of agreement: "It wouldn't pay for anyone to try to to force through something that would not get wide approval," he said.
"It makes no sense to seek a new future for the Union at the expense of small countries," Lipponen said.
